virus; TACE: transcatheter arterial chemoembolization.

' Refers to cirrhosis exhibiting morphological changes in the computed
tomography.

regions.crop_image_path: /mnt/sh_flex_storage/home/zehanyu/repos/GPT-Paper/pdfs/cancer_review/Multi-task deep learning network to predict future macrovascular invasion in hepatocellular carcinoma/crops_ordered/page_06/region_05_text.png
regions.text:
(N = 85). During the follow-ups, 45 patients had macrovascular inva-
sion (35 in the training dataset and ten in the validation dataset).
Excluding age, initial treatments, and maximum diameter of HCC
lesions, there were no statistical differences between the training
and validation datasets (Table 1).

regions.crop_image_path: /mnt/sh_flex_storage/home/zehanyu/repos/GPT-Paper/pdfs/cancer_review/Multi-task deep learning network to predict future macrovascular invasion in hepatocellular carcinoma/crops_ordered/page_06/region_06_title.png
regions.text: 3.2. Comparison among Model?®, Model, and Model®P8

regions.crop_image_path: /mnt/sh_flex_storage/home/zehanyu/repos/GPT-Paper/pdfs/cancer_review/Multi-task deep learning network to predict future macrovascular invasion in hepatocellular carcinoma/crops_ordered/page_06/region_07_text.png
regions.text:
Considering the three models (Model>®, Model“®, Model“P®), the
AUCs were 0-751, 0-822, and 0-877, respectively, in the training data-
set (Figure 4-A). The AUCs were 0-624, 0-770, and 0-836, respectively,
in the validation dataset (Figure 4-B). The statistical analysis based on
the Delong test, NRI, and IDI showed that Model 8 performed bet-
ter than Model and Model“. (Supplementary Table $2). Regarding
the calibration, although Model?® and Model® had an unsatisfactory
performance, Model©®P® was better both in the training and valida-
tion datasets (Figure 4-C and 4-D). In the decision curve, Model“® 8
also exhibited a better performance than Model?® and Model
(Figure 4-E). Therefore, Model©*?® proved to be the optimal model.
We constructed an applet accordingly (Figure 5, available at https://
drive.google.com/drive/folders/1UdjobJ_zX3E-E4q6eUyBAWjW
VutgM8PF?usp=sharing).

regions.crop_image_path: /mnt/sh_flex_storage/home/zehanyu/repos/GPT-Paper/pdfs/cancer_review/Multi-task deep learning network to predict future macrovascular invasion in hepatocellular carcinoma/crops_ordered/page_06/region_08_title.png
regions.text: 3.3. Subgroup and survival analysis using Model“ P®

regions.crop_image_path: /mnt/sh_flex_storage/home/zehanyu/repos/GPT-Paper/pdfs/cancer_review/Multi-task deep learning network to predict future macrovascular invasion in hepatocellular carcinoma/crops_ordered/page_06/region_09_text.png
regions.text:
The subgroup analysis showed that most clinical factors had lim-
ited influence on the performance of Model©®?® (Supplementary
Table S3), including age (p = 0-720; Supplementary Figure S2-A), sex

regions.crop_image_path: /mnt/sh_flex_storage/home/zehanyu/repos/GPT-Paper/pdfs/cancer_review/Multi-task deep learning network to predict future macrovascular invasion in hepatocellular carcinoma/crops_ordered/page_06/region_10_text.png
regions.text:
(p = 0-421; Supplementary Figure S2-B), treatments (p = 0-853; Sup-
plementary Figure S2-C), Child-Pugh class (p = 0-656; Supplementary
Figure S2-E), BCLC stage (0 vs. A: p = 0-802; A vs. B, p = 0-714; 0 vs. B,
p = 0-993; Supplementary Figure S2-F), max diameter (p = 0-533;
Figure S2-G), number of lesions (p = 0-480; Supplementary Figure S2-
H) and AFP level (<25 vs. 25-400: p = 0-065; <25 vs. >400,
p = 0.373; 25-400 vs. >400, p = 0-243; Supplementary Figure S2-I).
When patients were subdivided by radiologically confirmed cirrhosis,
the two subgroups were statistically different (p = 0-030; Supplemen-
tary Figure S2-D). However, compared to the AUC of 0-836 in the vali-
dation dataset, the difference was primarily caused by an increase in
the subgroup without cirrhosis (0-928), rather than a decrease in the
subgroup with cirrhosis (0.823).

regions.crop_image_path: /mnt/sh_flex_storage/home/zehanyu/repos/GPT-Paper/pdfs/cancer_review/Multi-task deep learning network to predict future macrovascular invasion in hepatocellular carcinoma/crops_ordered/page_06/region_11_text.png
regions.text:
The threshold of Model©®-?® (0.157) was identified using the You-
den index. Between the low-risk (risk < 0-157) and high-risk sub-
groups (risk > 0-157), there were statistical differences in the time to
macrovascular invasion in both the training (median: 1550 vs. infi-
nite days; hazard ratio [HR] = 0-073; 95% confidence interval [CI]:
0-032—0-167; p < 0-001; Figure 6-A) and validation (median: 645 vs.
infinite days; HR = 0-090; 95%CI: 0-022—0-366; p < 0-001; Figure 6-B)
datasets. Regarding the OS, the two subgroups also had statistical dif-
ferences in both the training (median: 360 vs. 617 days; HR = 0.344;
95%CI: 0:246—0.547; p < 0-001; Figure 6-C) and validation (median:
360 vs. 617 days; HR = 0-489; 95%CI: 0.279 — 0-859; p = 0-003;
Figure 6-D) datasets.

regions.crop_image_path: /mnt/sh_flex_storage/home/zehanyu/repos/GPT-Paper/pdfs/cancer_review/Multi-task deep learning network to predict future macrovascular invasion in hepatocellular carcinoma/crops_ordered/page_06/region_12_title.png
regions.text: 3.4. Analysis of image heterogeneity using Model®?*

regions.crop_image_path: /mnt/sh_flex_storage/home/zehanyu/repos/GPT-Paper/pdfs/cancer_review/Multi-task deep learning network to predict future macrovascular invasion in hepatocellular carcinoma/crops_ordered/page_06/region_13_text.png
regions.text:
The median of the image heterogeneity scores within the tumor
area (H-score) at 0-709 was also used to subdivide the patients.
Between the low-risk (H-scores < 0-709) and high-risk subgroups
(H-score > 0-709), there were statistically significant differences in
the time to macrovascular invasion in the training dataset
(HR = 0-352; 95% CI: 0-181—0-688; p = 0-003; Supplementary Figure
S3-A). Although there was a difference in the validation dataset, it
Was not statistically significant (HR = 0-195; 95%CI: 0-054—0-707;
p = 0-082; Supplementary Figure S3-B). Considering the OS, the two
subgroups showed statistical differences in both the training
(HR = 0-417; 95%CI: 0-289—0-603; p < 0-001; Supplementary Figure
S3-C) and validation (HR = 0.554; 95%CI: 0.345 — 0-892; p = 0-024;
Supplementary Figure S3-D) datasets.

regions.crop_image_path: /mnt/sh_flex_storage/home/zehanyu/repos/GPT-Paper/pdfs/cancer_review/Multi-task deep learning network to predict future macrovascular invasion in hepatocellular carcinoma/crops_ordered/page_06/region_14_title.png
regions.text: 3.5. Comparison between Model® 5°&-C8- PR and Model PR

regions.crop_image_path: /mnt/sh_flex_storage/home/zehanyu/repos/GPT-Paper/pdfs/cancer_review/Multi-task deep learning network to predict future macrovascular invasion in hepatocellular carcinoma/crops_ordered/page_06/region_15_text.png
regions.text:
Without the subnetwork for segmentation, ModelN° $°&-CRP® had
a lower AUC than Model“*?® (Training: 0-828 vs. 0-877; Validation:
0-759 vs. 0-836; Supplementary Figure S4-A, S4-B). The difference
was Statistically significant per the Delong test in both the training
and validation datasets (Supplementary Table S3). Furthermore,
Model%° S¢8-CR-PR had worse calibration than Model“? P®, especially
in the validation dataset (Supplementary Figure S4-C, S4-D). The
decreased performance in ModelN° $¢8-C®-PR proved the necessity of
the subnetwork for segmentation.

regions.crop_image_path: /mnt/sh_flex_storage/home/zehanyu/repos/GPT-Paper/pdfs/cancer_review/Multi-task deep learning network to predict future macrovascular invasion in hepatocellular carcinoma/crops_ordered/page_06/region_16_title.png

/mnt/sh_flex_storage/home/zehanyu/repos/GPT-Paper/pdfs/cancer_review/Multi-task deep learning network to predict future macrovascular invasion in hepatocellular carcinoma/crops_ordered/page_06/region_17_text.png
regions.text:
With regard to the clinical and radiological factors, the multivari-
ate logistic regression (backward: LR) identified the factors signifi-
cantly related to the macrovascular invasion, including the BCLC
stage, invasive shape, and anti-corona enhancement (Supplementary
Table $4 and $5). Model*sistic-CR-DR had a worse AUC than Model“ P®
(training: 0-810 vs. 0-877; validation: 0-790 vs. 0-836; Supplementary
Figure S5-A and S5-B). The difference was statistically significant per
the Delong test and IDI in the training dataset (Supplementary Table
S6). In addition, Model!sis-CR-PR showed a worse calibration than
Model®® in both datasets (Supplementary Figure S5-C and S5-D).
